Authors:
Thomas Schneider, Andy R. Vierstraete, Gert Jan van Pelt,
Max Caspers, Nataly Snegovaya, Ole Müller, Henri J. Dumont
Title:
Revision of the West-Palaearctic Cordulegaster by molecular
phylogeny and descriptive approach (Odonata: Anisoptera:
Cordulegastridae)
Abstract:
The genus Cordulegaster is one among three genera of the
family Cordulegastridae (Cordulegaster, Anotogaster, and Neaollogaster),
a relatively small and morphologically strongly conserved family of
robust, large, black-and-yellow coloured dragonflies. Thus,
Cordulegaster are present in the Old World and in the New World. The
genus is confined to special ecosystems with clear and fast flowing
brooks, creeks, and rivulets. The West-Palaearctic dragonflyfauna is one
of the best known and with little taxonomic problems. However, the
taxonomic situation of the Cordulegaster especially of the eastern
sector of the West-Palaearctis is still far from being well resolved.
The confusion is ongoing since over 170 years. The study by Froufe et
al. (2014) was the first using molecular approach, however, excluded the
more complex part of the eastern part with about 10 unsettled taxa. As
these taxa seem to be separated only recently hybridization on contact
zones may have occurred or still occurs, which underlines the limits of
phenotypical approaches using male appendices as the main discriminating
character. Therefore we used first a molecular approach using
mitochondrial and nuclear genes ((cytochrome c oxidase I (COI) and
Internal Trancribed Spacer-1 (ITS-1)). Our molecular results support the
old separation of the genus in the boltoni- and in the
bidentata-helladica-insignis group. However, C. coronata Morton, 1916
until now treated as a member of the latter belongs to neither of them,
and should be treated in a sister group of the
bidentata-helladica-insignis-group. In the eastern part of the W-
West-Palaearctic we found three known and one new species (C. heros
Teischinger, 1979, C. picta Selys, 1854, C. vanbrinkae Lohmann, 1993, C.
kalkmanae sp. nov.). We found no support for the subspecies C. heros
pelionensis (Teischinger, 1979). In the helladica-complex our results
support C. helladica (Lohmann, 1993) and C. buchholzi (Lohmann 1993) as
separate species, and we find no support for the subspecies C. helladica
kastalia (Lohmann, 1993), which is frequently a hybrid of C. bidentata
Selys, 1843 and C. helladica. In the insignis-complex our data support
the existence of 5 species: the nominate form in the SE-Europe and
W-Turkey, C. amasina Morton 1916, along the Black Sea cost including the
dark form often treated as C. mzymtae Bartenef, 1929; C. charpentieri
(Kolenati, 1846) including C. nobilis Morton, 1916 from E-Anatolia,
Georgia, Azerbaijan, N-Iran, and N-Iraq; C. cilicia sp. nov. along the
E-Mediterrane Coast reaching Lebanon, and E-Antolia; C. iranica sp. nov.
from S and SE-Iran. C. nachitschevanica Skvortsov & Snegovaya 2015
and C. plagionyx Skvortsov & Snegovaya 2015 were synonymized with C.
charpentieri. The Caucasus subspecies lagodechica and C. nobilis were
synonymized with C. charpentieri, and the E-Europe subspecies montandoni
St. Quentin, 1971 with nominate C. insignis (Schneider 1845). In a
second phenotypical step the new species (C. kalkmanae, C. cilica, C.
iranica) are described, and poorly defined species as C. amasina
(Morton), C. charpentieri (Kolenati, 1845) are re-described. Our
molecular analysis also included some New World and some E-Asian species
of the genus. Our data support a close relatedness of these
Cordulegaster of the old and new world suggesting that their disjunction
is of comparative recent date, probably Pliocene.
